title: How did Buddhism become Japan's state religion? - Quora

response.answer_text: Japan’s indigenous religion is Shinto, but aware of its civilizing effect and its association with more developed cultures on the continent, Japan’s aristocracy formally introduced Buddhism to Japan from the Korean kingdom of Paekche in 552. Buddhism’s central role in Japanese society was subsequently entrenched by Prince Shotoku via his Seventeen Article Constitution of 604, which called for reverence for the Buddha, his teachings, and the community of monks. At that time, Shinto was unorganized and essentially animistic, but rather than confront or overcome, it was characteristic of Buddhism’s philosophy of assimilation to incorporate. Consequently, by the Nara Era, the concept of honji suijaku (本地垂迹), whereby native Shintō deities were viewed as reified distillations (suijaku, 垂迹: traces) of primordial Buddhist principles (honji, 本地: prima materia), could be considered official government policy, as evident in the slogan shinbutsu shūgō (神仏習合): the identity of gods and Buddhas. Some, like Yoshida Kanetomo (1435-1511), came to argue that the relationship was the reverse, that Buddhist figures were “traces” of Shintō kami-gods, but had little success until the Meiji Restoration of 1868 and the advent of State Shintoism. At that time, to lessen the conservative anti-foreign influence of Buddhism and guard against foreign incursion by force, as had happened in China, the new slogans became shinbutsu bunri (神仏分離, the separateness of gods and buddhas), haibutsu kishaku (廃仏毀釈, abandon the Buddha, destroy Buddhism), and fukkoku kyōgun (福国強軍, enrich the nation, strengthen the army). Buddhist temples lost their land (i.e. wealth), and the political influence of Buddhism was to decrease in proportion to the rise of militaristic jingoism.

Japan’s state religion is Buddhism as mentioned in the constitution made by Shotoku Taishi which persists even today.
